required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Stepped Care Intervention to Reduce Disparities in Mental Health Services Among Cancer Patients and Caregivers
clinical_study.official_title: A Stepped-Care Intervention to Reduce Disparities in Mental Health Services Among Underserved Lung and Head and Neck Cancer Patients and Their Caregivers

brief_summary.textblock: Medically under-served (i.e., low-income, uninsured, underinsured) cancer patients generally encounter significant disparities in accessing care for their mental health needs while undergoing toxic treatments that provide considerable physical and emotional stress. Thus, the investigators propose to adapt evidence-based strategies to a stepped-care intervention model to address the mental health needs of under-served lung cancer (LC) and head and neck cancer (HNC) patients and their caregivers across several levels of symptom severity (e.g., mild, moderate, or severe symptoms of depression and anxiety).

primary_outcome.description: Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS)-Cancer (CA) Form v1.0 - Depression (30 items). The range is from 8 to 40. Higher score indicates worse outcome (higher depression). Raw scores were used in analyses.

Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System, Anxiety (PROMIS-Ca) Form v1.0- Anxiety (22 items). The range of scores is between 8 and 40. The raw scores were used. Higher score corresponds to worse outcome.
Coping Self-Efficacy (26 items). Scores can rage from 0 to 260. Higher score corresponds to better outcome.

secondary_outcome.description: Coping Self-Efficacy (26 items). Higher score corresponds to better outcome. Scores can rage from 0 to 260. The number of caregivers randomized and analyzed was 118 and 131 in the enhanced usual care and intervention groups, respectively.

PROMIS Form v1.0 - Anxiety (29 items). The range of scores is from 8 to 40. Higher score indicates worse outcome (higher anxiety). Raw scores were used in analyses. The number of caregivers randomized and analyzed was 118 and 131 in the enhanced usual care and intervention groups, respectively.

PROMIS Form v1.0 - Depression (28 items). The range is from 8 to 40. Higher score indicates worse outcome (higher depression). Raw scores were used in analyses. The number of caregivers randomized and analyzed was 118 and 131 in the enhanced usual care and intervention groups, respectively.
FACT-G version 4 (27 items). The range is 0-108. Higher values indicate better QOL.
Perceived Stress Scale (PSS) (14 items). The range of scores is 0-40. Higher values indicate higher stress.
Perceived Stress Scale (PSS) (14 items). The range is from 0 to 40. Higher values indicate higher stress.
Zarit Burden Interview (ZBI) (12 items). The range of scores is 0-48. Higher scores represent higher burden.

arm_group.description: Intervention strategies are grounded in evidence-based Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), that includes stress management and relaxation treatment strategies and coping skills training. Treatment strategies have been adapted from the Transactional Model of Stress and Coping (TMSC), a theoretical model that predicts that individuals who are able to cope and adapt to the stress related to cancer treatment or caregiving will report less psychological distress than those unable to cope.

Denver Health, St. Mary's and St. Joseph's hospitals provide supportive mental health care for patients such as printed materials, support groups, crisis counseling, and specialized care (e.g., psychiatric medication). Because the amount of usual mental health care that each patient receives varies at each site, the investigators will standardize and monitor the usual care arm across the three sites with an enhanced usual care condition.

intervention.description: The intervention delivered evidence-based CBT and stress management across eight counseling sessions.
Consists of a list of standard mental health resources offered at the participating hospital, local community, or national non-profit organizations.

facility.name: Saint Mary's Hospital and Regional Medical Center

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Both patients and caregivers were recruited for this study. Primary outcomes data were focused on patients. Caregiver data were included as secondary analyses.

group.description: Patients who were randomized to Enhanced Usual Care

group.description: Total of all reporting groups

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measure.title: Diagnosis
measure.population: Diagnosis data were not collected from caregivers.

measure.title: Cancer Stage
measure.description: Cancer Stage were clinically diagnosed by medical oncologists at each site and were self-reported by patients in the baseline survey. The cancer stages varied between stage 0, I, II, III, and IV with IV being the most advanced.
measure.population: No cancer stage was collected from the caregivers.

measure.title: Step at Baseline
measure.description: The treatment steps that participants were assigned to, based on their personal level of distress included: Step 1: Watchful Waiting Step 2: Self-Help Guide Step 3: Coping Skills Training Step 4: Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy

outcome.title: Symptoms of Depression-Patients
outcome.description: Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS)-Cancer (CA) Form v1.0 - Depression (30 items). The range is from 8 to 40. Higher score indicates worse outcome (higher depression). Raw scores were used in analyses.
outcome.population: Intention to treat population- all participants who were randomized were included in this analysis. The reported means correspond to the observed means at 6 months.

group.title: Patients in Enhanced Usual Care
group.description: Patients who were randomized to Enhanced Usual Care

group.title: Patients in Stepped Care Intervention
group.description: Patients who were randomized to the Stepped Care Intervention

measure.title: Symptoms of Depression-Patients
measure.description: Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System (PROMIS)-Cancer (CA) Form v1.0 - Depression (30 items). The range is from 8 to 40. Higher score indicates worse outcome (higher depression). Raw scores were used in analyses.
measure.population: Intention to treat population- all participants who were randomized were included in this analysis. The reported means correspond to the observed means at 6 months.

analysis.groups_desc: A linear mixed model (LMM) with random intercepts for both patients and clinics has been used, with adjustment for cancer type and cancer stage. The study was powered for testing the hypothesis of no group differences in change over the four time points (baseline, 6-weeks, 3-months and 6-months). A significant group by time interaction was hypothesized.
analysis.p_value_desc: Since there are three primary outcomes (depression, anxiety and coping scores) in the study, the significance level was set a priori at 0.0167 (alpha = 0.05/3).
analysis.method_desc: The pvalue corresponds to the hypothesis of the interaction effect between time and group (intervention arm).
analysis.estimate_desc: The estimate represents the difference in expected means at the 6-month time point between the intervention and usual care arms.

outcome.title: Symptoms of Anxiety-Patients
outcome.description: Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System, Anxiety (PROMIS-Ca) Form v1.0- Anxiety (22 items). The range of scores is between 8 and 40. The raw scores were used. Higher score corresponds to worse outcome.

group.title: Enhanced Usual Care
group.description: Enhanced Usual Care: Consists of a list of standard mental health resources offered at the participating hospital, local community, or national non-profit organizations.

group.title: Stepped-Care Intervention
group.description: Intervention strategies are grounded in evidence-based Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), that includes stress management and relaxation treatment strategies and coping skills training. Treatment strategies have been adapted from the Transactional Model of Stress and Coping (TMSC), a theoretical model that predicts that individuals who are able to cope and adapt to the stress related to cancer treatment or caregiving will report less psychological distress than those unable to cope. Stepped-Care Intervention: The intervention delivered evidence-based CBT and stress management across eight counseling sessions.

measure.title: Symptoms of Anxiety-Patients
measure.description: Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System, Anxiety (PROMIS-Ca) Form v1.0- Anxiety (22 items). The range of scores is between 8 and 40. The raw scores were used. Higher score corresponds to worse outcome.

analysis.groups_desc: Linear mixed models (LMM) have been used with time and the interaction between time and group as fixed effects. A structure of random effects that includes random intercepts for patients was used. The study was powered for testing the hypothesis of no group differences in change over the four time points. A significant group by time interaction was hypothesized.
analysis.p_value_desc: Since there are three primary outcomes (depression, anxiety and coping scores) in the study, the significance level was set a priori at 0.0167 (alpha = 0.05/3).
analysis.method_desc: The pvalue corresponds to the hypothesis of the interaction effect between time and group (intervention arm).
analysis.estimate_desc: The estimate represents the difference in expected means at the 6-month time point between the intervention and usual care arms.

outcome.title: Change in Coping-Patients
outcome.description: Coping Self-Efficacy (26 items). Scores can rage from 0 to 260. Higher score corresponds to better outcome.

group.title: Enhanced Usual Care
group.description: Enhanced Usual Care: Consists of a list of standard mental health resources offered at the participating hospital, local community, or national non-profit organizations.

group.title: Stepped-Care Intervention
group.description: Intervention strategies are grounded in evidence-based Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), that includes stress management and relaxation treatment strategies and coping skills training. Treatment strategies have been adapted from the Transactional Model of Stress and Coping (TMSC), a theoretical model that predicts that individuals who are able to cope and adapt to the stress related to cancer treatment or caregiving will report less psychological distress than those unable to cope. Stepped-Care Intervention: The intervention delivered evidence-based CBT and stress management across eight counseling sessions.

measure.title: Change in Coping-Patients
measure.description: Coping Self-Efficacy (26 items). Scores can rage from 0 to 260. Higher score corresponds to better outcome.

analysis.groups_desc: Linear mixed models (LMM) have been used with time and the interaction between time and group as fixed effects. A structure of random effects that includes random intercepts for patients was used. The study was powered for testing the hypothesis of no group differences in change over the four time points. A significant group by time interaction was hypothesized.
analysis.p_value_desc: Since there are three primary outcomes (depression, anxiety and coping scores) in the study, the significance level was set a priori at 0.0167 (alpha = 0.05/3).
analysis.method_desc: The pvalue corresponds to the hypothesis of an interaction between time and intervention arm.
analysis.estimate_desc: The estimate represents the difference in expected means at the 6-month time point between the intervention and usual care arms.

reported_events.time_frame: Between baseline through the six month follow-up. Adverse events can be reported by the study coordinators at anytime from baseline through completion of the 6 month follow-up.

event.description: Head-and-neck/lung cancer or complications related to the diagnoses

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
